title: This is what the internet looks like now
content:
You can find audio versions of Garbage Day on every major podcasting app (search â€œGarbage Dayâ€ and look for the trash can). If itâ€™s not there, hereâ€™s an RSS feed.

Whatâ€™s The End Goal Here?

Disturbing trend on TT/YT/IG: entire social channels with nonsense recipes. They're clearly narrated by AI and likely written by it, but the videos appear real. The channels have no affiliate websites, but millions of subs. It's just chaos.

Like this egg horror:

â€” Max Meyer (@mualphaxi)
May 7, 2024

A few different readers sent me the above video this week. Itâ€™s a nonsensical recipe that uses an AI voice for narration and is currently stuck in everyoneâ€™s algorithm. It checks a lot of my boxes! It comes from a page called @SuperRecipess, which posted it to TikTok in March 2023. It currently has 24 million views on the app, with millions more on other platforms.

Super Recipes, according to their Facebook page, is a digital media â€œbrand,â€ owned by Brazilian company called Ls Mota Negocios Digitais LTDA, who run several over similar pages. Thereâ€™s one called YumMakers, another called SuperGostoso (Supertasty), and another called Recetas de Jefe (Chefâ€™s Recipes). The recipes theyâ€™re putting on their Portuguese-language pages are decidedly less disgusting than the ones theyâ€™re posting in English â€” insert Brazilian jokes about American slop food here â€” but most of what theyâ€™re doing is now standard practice. A frying pan, eggs, cheese, hot dogs, more cheese, oil, stuff stuffed with other stuff. As one user on X wrote underneath the video, â€œImagine this being the entire internet.â€ Well, we donâ€™t have to imagine. This is what the internet looks like now.

Across the social web, older forms of low-effort engagement bait are getting a brand new coat of AI paint. Every time I poke around a random TikTok that ends up on my For You Page, I, without fail, find out itâ€™s connected to some weird content farm pumping out AI images on Facebook. I shared a couple little investigations into this on TikTok before I got bored lol. Also, my dumb old person thumbs just cannot figure out how to edit video on a phone and I find the entire process excruciating.

The most interesting page Iâ€™ve come across was a TikTok account called @greatmovie05, which has half a million followers on TikTok. Like @SuperRecipess, it takes a well-trod genre of viral content, in this case what Iâ€™m going to call â€œ12-year-old boy newsâ€ â€” videos about Russian prisons, cool boat facts, dashcam recordings, stories about guys getting stuck in caves â€” and uses an AI to narrate and, likely, write and compile them.

I managed to find a Facebook Page with the same user name, sharing the same videos that itâ€™s posting on TikTok. And when itâ€™s not sharing those videos, you know what itâ€™s doing? Generating AI photos of Jesus. And I found another Facebook Page with the same user name, sharing the same videos, which is generating bizarre AI images of children in South Asian villages driving, uh, like go karts made from plastic bottles?

(idk manâ€¦)

The question I have, which I wrote above, is what is the end goal with all of this? Itâ€™s clear that, for creators, this is just another engagement hack. Something you can quickly spit out to enrage old people and mesmerize iPad babies. But Iâ€™m less clear how anyone at Meta, or Youtube, or TikTok can look at this and think that itâ€™s good. To say nothing of those platformsâ€™ advertisers.

Last week, 404 MediaÂ coined the term â€œzombie internet,â€ to refer to this endless wasteland of algorithmically-regurgitated, and now AI-generated, content filling up Meta platforms and, thus, everywhere else. Itâ€™s a problem that has gotten so bad that Instagramâ€™s official account, this week, appears to have fallen for an AI-generated photo of Katy Perry at the Met Gala. Which is especially funny because while Katy Perry was not at the Met Gala this week, Instagram head Adam Mosseri was there taking videos on the red carpet with his Meta Ray-Bans. Canâ€™t really come up with a better indictment of how thoroughly Big Tech has broken our ability to understand the world around us than that.

The following is a paid ad. If youâ€™re interested in advertising, email me at ryan@garbageday.email and letâ€™s talk. Thanks!

Sick of robocalls, spam emails, stalkers, frauds, and annoying uses of your personal data?

Every day, data brokers profit from your sensitive info â€” your phone number, DOB, SSN â€” selling it to the highest bidder. And who's buying it? Well, the best case is itâ€™s just companies thatâ€™ll target you with ads. Which still isnâ€™t great. The worst case, though, are scammers and identity thieves.Â 

Try Incogni â€” not only does it delete your personal data from the web, but it also removes your info from sites used for stalking.

This Is How I Feel All The Time Now

@zachwoods

Bae caught me slipping into obscurity. #comedy #icespice #filters

Some (Hopefully) Final Kendrick/Drake Updates

A literary feud involving two men named Kendrick Lamar Duckworth and Aubrey Drake Graham is giving 19th century.

â€” Andrew Marzoni (@andrewmarzoni)
May 5, 2024

The Kendrick/Drake rap beef has reached its inevitable, and very dark, conclusion, with Drakeâ€™s security guard being shot in a drive-by outside of the rapperâ€™s mansion. Drakeâ€™s store in London was also vandalized. I suppose it shouldnâ€™t be surprising that the 21st century version of the Tupac/Biggie rap beef of the 90s has devolved into decentralized QAnon-style mob violence and â€” just to be clear here â€” still baseless accusations of pedophilia and human trafficking.

There also now a lot of conspiracy theories flying around. The biggest of which is the rumor the Universal Music Group stepped in to stop the feud which, according to TMZ, is not true. Though, on the bright side, creators are making an incredible amount of money thanks to Kendrick Lamarâ€™s decision to not enforce a copyright on his diss tracks.

Chaotic violence and viral conspiracies aside, Lamarâ€™s four diss tracks are smashing streaming records. And itâ€™s likely at least one of them will enter Billboardâ€™s Hot 100 next week. As a rapper named DuffJuice wrote on X, â€œThis means something. This means A LOT actually.â€

I am resisting the urge to connect this to Taylor Swift releasing what is essentially also a 31-track diss record about The 1975â€™s Matty Healy last month and going long here about the new, darker, hyperreal era of pop culture thatâ€™s coming into focus right now. But I do think thatâ€™s whatâ€™s happening.

Apple Has Finally Released, Uh, Slightly Better iPads

Meet the new iPad Pro: the thinnest product weâ€™ve ever created, the most advanced display weâ€™ve ever produced, with the incredible power of the M4 chip. Just imagine all the things itâ€™ll be used to create.

â€” Tim Cook (@tim_cook)
May 7, 2024

Apple released an ad for their new M4 iPad Pro this morning, which features a giant hydraulic press crushing things that people use to create art and express themselves down into slime and goo. Which, I know I just said Adam Mosseri filming metaverse content at the Met Gala while AI images of the event wreak havoc on his platform was the best metaphor you could ask for to describe Where We Are Right Now, but this might be better.

On X, based on the replies to Apple CEO Tim Cookâ€™s tweet, Japanese users seem to be particularly enraged by the ad. But I thought New Republicâ€™s Osita Nwanevu had a good take, writing, â€œThe very existence of this ad â â€” all the hoops it had to go through in its creation before getting to the point where it was personally promoted by this CEO, all the people who thought 'yes, this is good' â€” says more than thousands of words could about how tech sees the world.â€

But perhaps the worst reaction to this morningâ€™s iPad drop was from Apple superfan Marques Brownlee, who seemed to really struggle to say anything nice about it. Sorry Iâ€™m mentioning him a lot lately, but weâ€™re in a real gadget moment right now and itâ€™s literally just him and The Verge covering these rollouts aggressively. (I actually shopped a Garbage Day gadget review column and/or video series around to a couple media outlets a few months ago because itâ€™s not something I can really afford on my own and found that editors werenâ€™t super interested ğŸ‘€)

Anyways, the new iPad is thin and the pencil can do a barrel roll now, I guess.

X Is Raging Over A New TikTok Woman

A girl finds a creative way to express her anger.

â€” Catch Up (@CatchUpFeed)
May 7, 2024

I know I shouldnâ€™t take the bait with this stuff, but this morning I decided to look into the new woman that everyone on X is yelling about right now. She posts on TikTok under the name @livingthrulove and, based on her content, it seems like sheâ€™s a small creator sharing updates about what itâ€™s like being a new mother. And this, of course, is too much for the average X user to handle.

The main account leading the dog pile on @livingthrulove is called @CatchUpFeed and theyâ€™ve been a big winner of the Elon Musk era of X. I see their posts a lot. Theyâ€™re sort of like a right-wing Pop Crave and I was curious what their whole deal is.

Well, it turns out their Facebook page was launched in 2016, back when it had a different name, â€œIan Miles Cheongâ€. The far-right influencer and president of Muskâ€™s fan club seems to have rebranded the page as Catch Up in 2022. That was also when it launched a YouTube channel that was, for about a year, hosted by Cheong. The Facebook page is now being run by someone out of the UK (Cheong lives in Malaysia) and the YouTube channel has a new host.

Everyoneâ€™s Talking About John Pork

(TikTok/John Pork)

TikTok is going nuts for John Pork. As are Vancouver burger joints, apparently. Who is John Pork? Well, it should be obvious, heâ€™s a somewhat horrifying-looking humanoid pig man that all the TikTok girlies canâ€™t get enough of.

But in all seriousness, John Pork is a virtual influencer that launched on Instagram in 2018. Over the last few years, Pork has evolved. First into a piece of creepypasta, with TikTok users writing scary stories about him and, now, inevitably, everyoneâ€™s kind of horny for him.

4chan Users Have Overrun A Dating App

(/soc/)

The developers of an app called Duolicious dropped their app on 4chan and it has, predictably, turned into a horror show. More than a few folks are now calling it the â€œfemcel dating app,â€ but, based on the screenshots Iâ€™m seeing, it seems like itâ€™s overwhelming popular with 20-year-old guys who own Nazi memorabilia.

Itâ€™s worth pointing out here how far the Overton window has moved in the last decade. Ten years ago, if 4chan users set up shop on your site, youâ€™d end up with a dozen cable news packages about how youâ€™re facilitating extremism and, in certain instances, you might even lose your hosting. Now, Duolicious is posting 4chan screenshots on their official site, bragging about their traffic on X, and using Ko-fi to manage donations.
